importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Admiral Alvin Holsey served as commander of US Southern Command, from November 2024 to December 12, 2025, during which he oversaw military operations in the Caribbean and faced internal tensions with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth.

keyTakeAways: Admiral Alvin Holsey, the commander of U.S. Southern Command, is retiring one year into his tenure, effective December 12, 2025.
Holsey oversaw U.S. military operations in the Caribbean, including controversial drug-related strikes off the coast of Venezuela, which have raised legal and ethical concerns.

Tensions arose between Holsey and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over the pace and legality of counter-narcotics operations; Holsey expressed concerns about lack of information and legal compliance, while Hegseth believed operations were insufficiently aggressive.

The Pentagon denied claims that Holsey expressed reservations about the legality of operations in the Caribbean, although sources indicated internal disagreements over operational strategy and legal boundaries.

This retirement comes shortly after a fifth known U.S. strike on a drug-trafficking boat off Venezuela, killing six people, and one day after President Donald Trump publicly authorized CIA operations in Venezuela to curb drug and migrant flows.
Holsey has served in the U.S. Navy for 37 years, including as commander of Carrier Strike Group One and Military Deputy Commander at Southern Command.
Holsey succeeded Army Gen. Laura Richardson, who served as Southern Command commander from 2021 to 2025.
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has replaced several high-ranking military officials since assuming office, indicating broader shifts in military leadership and strategy.
The retirement of Holsey signals potential shifts in U.S. policy toward drug enforcement in Latin America, especially in Venezuela, where operations have intensified recently.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Admiral Alvin Holsey, commander of U.S. Southern Command and responsible for U.S. military operations in the Caribbean, is retiring at the end of 2025, one year after assuming office. His departure follows a period of escalating military actions—including a fifth known strike on a drug-trafficking vessel off Venezuela's coast, which killed six people—and growing tensions with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over the pace and legality of counter-narcotics operations. While Holsey expressed concerns about legal compliance and lack of information, Hegseth criticized the operations as insufficiently aggressive. The retirement comes amid broader political developments, including President Donald Trump’s public authorization of CIA operations in Venezuela to curb drug and migrant flows, and the deployment of B-52 bombers off the Venezuelan coast. Holsey, who has served in the Navy for 37 years, is succeeded by a new commander, signaling a potential shift in U.S. strategy toward drug enforcement in the region.
title: Commander overseeing US forces in the Caribbean to retire one year into tenure
